metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Python If ... Else
Python Conditions and If statements
Python supports the usual logical conditions from mathematics:
content.html: Python supports the usual logical conditions from mathematics:

content.text: These conditions can be used in several ways, most commonly in "if statements" and loops.
content.html: These conditions can be used in several ways, most commonly in "if statements" and loops.

content.text: An "if statement" is written by using the if keyword.
content.html: An "if statement" is written by using the if keyword.

content.code_html:
a = 33
b = 200
if b > a:
  print("b is greater than a")

content.text: In this example we use two variables, a and b , which are used as part of the if statement to test whether b is greater than a . As a is 33 , and b is 200 , we know that 200 is greater than 33, and so we print to screen that "b is greater than a".
content.html: In this example we use two variables, a and b, which are used as part of the if statement to test whether b is greater than a. As a is 33, and b is 200, we know that 200 is greater than 33, and so we print to screen that "b is greater than a".

content.text: Indentation
Python relies on indentation (whitespace at the beginning of a line) to define scope in the code. Other programming languages often use curly-brackets for this purpose.
content.html: Python relies on indentation (whitespace at the beginning of a line) to define scope in the code. Other programming languages often use curly-brackets for this purpose.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
a = 33
b = 200
if b > a:
print("b is greater than a")
# you will get an error

content.code:
a = 33
b = 200
if b > a:
print("b is greater than a")
# you will get an error

syntax_highlighting.text:
a = 33
b = 200
if b > a:
print("b is greater than a")
# you will get an error

content.code_html:
a = 33
b = 200
if b > a:
print("b is greater than a") # you will get an error

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
a = 33
b = 200
if b > a:
print("b is greater than a")
# you will get an error

content.text: Elif
The elif keyword is Python's way of saying "if the previous conditions were not true, then try this condition".
content.html: The elif keyword is Python's way of saying "if the previous conditions were not true, then try this condition".

content.code_html:
a = 33
b = 33
if b > a:
  print("b is greater than a")
elif a == b:
  print("a and b are equal")

content.text: In this example a is equal to b , so the first condition is not true, but the elif condition is true, so we print to screen that "a and b are equal".
content.html: In this example a is equal to b, so the first condition is not true, but the elif condition is true, so we print to screen that "a and b are equal".

content.text: Else
The else keyword catches anything which isn't caught by the preceding conditions.
content.html: The else keyword catches anything which isn't caught by the preceding conditions.

content.code_html:
a = 200
b = 33
if b > a:
  print("b is greater than a")
elif a == b:
  print("a and b are equal")
else:
  print("a is greater than b")

content.text: In this example a is greater than b , so the first condition is not true, also the elif condition is not true, so we go to the else condition and print to screen that "a is greater than b".
content.html: In this example a is greater than b, so the first condition is not true, also the elif condition is not true, so we go to the else condition and print to screen that "a is greater than b".

content.text: You can also have an else without the elif :
content.html: You can also have an else without the elif:

content.code_html:
a = 200
b = 33
if b > a:
  print("b is greater than a")
else:
  print("b is not greater than a")

content.text: Short Hand If
If you have only one statement to execute, you can put it on the same line as the if statement.
content.html: If you have only one statement to execute, you can put it on the same line as the if statement.

syntaxHighlighting.text: if a > b: print("a is greater than b")

content.code: if a > b: print("a is greater than b")

syntax_highlighting.text: if a > b: print("a is greater than b")

content.code_html: if a > b: print("a is greater than b")

syntax_highlighting_data.text: if a > b: print("a is greater than b")

content.text: Short Hand If ... Else
If you have only one statement to execute, one for if, and one for else, you can put it all on the same line:
content.html: If you have only one statement to execute, one for if, and one for else, you can put it all on the same line:

syntaxHighlighting.text: a = 2b = 330print("A") if a > b else print("B")

content.code: a = 2b = 330print("A") if a > b else print("B")

syntax_highlighting.text: a = 2b = 330print("A") if a > b else print("B")

content.code_html:
a = 2
b = 330
print("A") if a > b else print("B")

syntax_highlighting_data.text: a = 2b = 330print("A") if a > b else print("B")

content.text: This technique is known as Ternary Operators , or Conditional Expressions .
content.html: This technique is known as Ternary Operators, or Conditional Expressions.

content.text: You can also have multiple else statements on the same line:
content.html: You can also have multiple else statements on the same line:

syntaxHighlighting.text: a = 330b = 330print("A") if a > b else print("=") if a == b else print("B")

content.code: a = 330b = 330print("A") if a > b else print("=") if a == b else print("B")

syntax_highlighting.text: a = 330b = 330print("A") if a > b else print("=") if a == b else print("B")

content.code_html:
a = 330
b = 330
print("A") if a > b else print("=") if a == b else print("B")

syntax_highlighting_data.text: a = 330b = 330print("A") if a > b else print("=") if a == b else print("B")

content.text: And
The and keyword is a logical operator, and is used to combine conditional statements:
content.html: The and keyword is a logical operator, and is used to combine conditional statements:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
a = 200b = 33c = 500if a > b and c > a:
	 
	print("Both conditions are True")

content.code:
a = 200b = 33c = 500if a > b and c > a:

print("Both conditions are True")

syntax_highlighting.text:
a = 200b = 33c = 500if a > b and c > a:
 
	print("Both conditions are True")

content.code_html:
a = 200
b = 33
c = 500
if a > b and c > a:
  print("Both conditions are True")

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
a = 200b = 33c = 500if a > b and c > a:
	 
	print("Both conditions are True")

content.text: Or
The or keyword is a logical operator, and is used to combine conditional statements:
content.html: The or keyword is a logical operator, and is used to combine conditional statements:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
a = 200b = 33c = 500if a > b or a > c:
	 
	print("At least one of the conditions is True")
"At least one of the conditions is True"

content.code:
a = 200b = 33c = 500if a > b or a > c:

print("At least one of the conditions is True")

syntax_highlighting.text:
a = 200b = 33c = 500if a > b or a > c:
 
	print("At least one of the conditions is True")
"At least one of the conditions is True"

b = 33
c = 500
if a > b or a > c:
  print("At least one of the conditions is True")

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
a = 200b = 33c = 500if a > b or a > c:
	 
	print("At least one of the conditions is True")
"At least one of the conditions is True"

content.text: Not
The not keyword is a logical operator, and is used to reverse the result of the conditional statement:
content.html: The not keyword is a logical operator, and is used to reverse the result of the conditional statement:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
a = 33b = 200if not a > b:
	 
	print("a is NOT greater than b")

content.code:
a = 33b = 200if not a > b:

print("a is NOT greater than b")

syntax_highlighting.text:
a = 33b = 200if not a > b:
 
	print("a is NOT greater than b")

content.code_html:
a = 33
b = 200
if not a > b:
  print("a is NOT greater than b")

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
a = 33b = 200if not a > b:
	 
	print("a is NOT greater than b")

content.text: Nested If
You can have if statements inside if statements, this is called nested if statements.
content.html: You can have if statements inside if statements, this is called nested if statements.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
x = 41if x > 10:
	 
	print("Above ten,")  if x > 20:    print("and 
  also above 20!")  else:    print("but not 
  above 20.")

content.code:
x = 41if x > 10:

print("Above ten,")  if x > 20:    print("and
also above 20!")  else:    print("but not
above 20.")

syntax_highlighting.text:
x = 41if x > 10:
 
	print("Above ten,")  if x > 20:    print("and 
  also above 20!")  else:    print("but not 
  above 20.")

content.code_html:
x = 41

if x > 10:
  print("Above ten,")
  if x > 20:
    print("and also above 20!")
  else:
    print("but not above 20.")

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
x = 41if x > 10:
	 
	print("Above ten,")  if x > 20:    print("and 
  also above 20!")  else:    print("but not 
  above 20.")

content.text: The pass Statement
if statements cannot be empty, but if you for some reason have an if statement with no content, put in the pass statement to avoid getting an error.
content.html: if statements cannot be empty, but if you for some reason have an if statement with no content, put in the pass statement to avoid getting an error.

content.code_html:
a = 33
b = 200

if b > a:
  pass

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
What will be the result of the following code: x = 5 y = 8 if x > y: print('Hello') else: print('Welcome')
content.html:
What will be the result of the following code:
x = 5
y = 8
if x > y:
  print('Hello')
else:
  print('Welcome')
